371aaea8-195e21b2-ba5a2856-54803ecf-1b72:
Dr. David J. Kim
Dr. David J. Kim is an Assistant Professor of Radiology at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston. He received his medical degree from the University of Texas Medical School at Houston and completed his residency in Diagnostic Radiology at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Texas. His clinical interests include thoracic imaging, interventional radiology, and musculoskeletal imaging.
Dr. Kim is a member of the American Roentgen Ray Society, the Society of Chest Radiologists, the Society of Interventional Radiology, and the American College of Radiology

Chest x-ray of the patient shows a large right pleural effusion with no evidence of pneumothorax. The left hemithorax is well aerated. There is no mediastinal widening or lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A. Pleural mesothelioma
B. Tuberculous pleurisy
C. Pneumonia
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. None of the above
Answer: A

49f3fbfe-cb406005-e8999546-2f5f2217-cd34:
The chest xray image is a comprehensive and detailed diagnosis report for this procedure. It includes all relevant information about the patient's condition, including detailed clinical findings and laboratory test results. If these results become available, they will be automatically included in the final report.
There are no restrictions on image storage. Image archiving is at your discretion.
Results are of sufficient quality to be of diagnostic value.
Indications for use of this procedure
X-ray imaging of the chest may be indicated for the following indications:
- Diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis
- Detection of lung cancer
